sn4.22:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near Silāvatī.
sn4.22:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Samiddhi was meditating not far from the Buddha, diligent, keen, and resolute.
sn4.22:1.3: Then as Venerable Samiddhi was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
sn4.22:1.5: to have a teacher who is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha!
sn4.22:1.6: I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,
sn4.22:1.7: to have gone forth in a teaching and training so well explained!
sn4.22:1.8: I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,
sn4.22:1.9: to have spiritual companions who are ethical and of good character.”
sn4.22:1.10: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing what Samiddhi was thinking, went up to him and made a terrifyingly loud noise close by him. It seemed as if the earth was shattering.
sn4.22:2.1: Then Samiddhi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said,
sn4.22:3.2: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!
sn4.22:3.3: Go back to that same place, Samiddhi, and meditate, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
sn4.22:3.4: “Yes, sir,” replied Samiddhi. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
sn4.22:3.5: And for a second time Samiddhi was meditating in that same place, diligent, ardent, and resolute.
sn4.22:3.6: And for a second time he had the same thought …
sn4.22:3.7: and Māra made an earth-shattering noise.
sn4.22:3.9: Then Samiddhi addressed Māra the Wicked One in verse:
sn4.22:4.2: from the lay life to homelessness.
sn4.22:4.3: My mindfulness and wisdom are mature,
sn4.22:4.4: my mind is serene in immersion.
sn4.22:5.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The mendicant Samiddhi knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
